newsitem.title: USA: Smokers trying to quit can now use inhaler device.
newsitem.headline: Smokers trying to quit can now use inhaler device.

text.p: People trying to quit smoking who want an alternative to nicotine patches and chewing gum could use an inhalable alternative that uses typical smoker's behaviour, health officials said on Monday.
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said it approved the Nicotrol Inhaler, a nicotine inhalation system for prescription use.
The person trying to quit gets the nicotine replacement therapy by inhaling through a cartridge placed in a mouthpiece.

Advanced Therapeutic Products Inc., which developed the device, said it is the first form of nicotine replacement therapy to help control a smoker's craving for cigarettes but also provide one of the behavioural patterns that goes with smoking, the hand-to-mouth ritual.

The FDA said it is not known if the product satisfies that psychological need for the hand-mouth ritual. But clinical trials have shown that the quit rates were comparable to other smoking cessation products on the market.
Some of the alternative methods are sold over-the-counter but the Inhaler will be available by prescription.

In 1987, the company sold patented nicotine technology, which forms the basis of the Inhaler, to what is now Pharmacia & Upjohn in exhange for future product payments equal to about three percent of net sales to wholesale distributors.
The Inhaler will be marketed in the U.S. as the Nicotrol Inhaler by McNeil Consumer Products, a Johnson & Johnson company.

Outside the U.S.,the Inhaler is marketed by Pharmacia & Upjohn as the Nicorette Inhaler and is available over-the-counter in Denmark, Sweden and Italy, with applications pending for over-the-counter sales in five other countries including the United Kingdom.
